The enemy's fire was good for direction, but badly laid for elevation, and no damage was done to the ships. By 10.45 a.m. the enemy's guns w'ere almost silenced. The Oxfordshire Light Infantry had cleared the enemy off the sandhills, but the troops were now entangled in the marshy ground in front of the enemy's main position, part of which seems to have been on the south side of Rota Creek. A large body of infantry, estimated at between one and two thousand men, coming from Sachricha to reinforce this position, was dispersed by the Espiegles fire. Plan 5.
